title: Putting ice packs on injuries does more harm than good, RICE inventor says
text:
Ask any parent, or indeed most physiotherapists: the best way to deal with a nasty sprain is to reach immediately for a soothing ice pack or packet of frozen peas.

Not only does the intense cold numb the pain, it also cuts down on damaging inflammation.

That, at any rate, is the theory, one intuitively believed by most amateur sportsmen and women and adhered to by the majority of practitioners.

However, this has now been challenged by none other than the scientist who wrote the original rules on using ice to treat injuries.

Dr Gabe Mirkin, who in 1978 helped draft the RICE guidance - Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation - now believes the practice does more harm than good.
